request_pathways.name: Authorization to Disclose Protected Health Information (English)
Autorización Para Divulgar Información de Salud Protegida (Spanish)
Fax submission of completed authorization form
Mail submission of completed authorization form

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a general-purpose HIPAA authorization PDF, selects 'Personal Use' from nine disclosure reasons, fills in both authorizing-party and recipient fields (naming themselves), prints, signs, and faxes or mails the form.

red_flags: Right of Access acknowledgment (form not required for patient self-access) is buried in supplementary legal text on page 2, not surfaced on the main form
Fillable PDF fields lack semantic names, impairing screen reader accessibility
bright_spots: Professionally translated Spanish version available as parallel download
Reproductive health protections current with 2024 federal rule (dedicated Prohibited Use Attestation page)
Treatment-not-conditioned statement prominently placed at top of page 1
Email offered as a records delivery method
16 granular record-type checkboxes give patients meaningful control over disclosure scope

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — dedicated Medical Records page reachable from footer in one click, with clear download links and a 3-step process explanation; minor deduction for dead legacy URLs from site migration.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital with one gap — thoroughly fillable PDF (95 interactive fields) allows digital completion, but patient must print, sign, and fax or mail to submit; no e-signature or online submission option.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor issues — logical flow, clear all-caps section headers, 16 granular record-type checkboxes, and plain-language opening instructions; minor deductions for grammatical error in fee language and unlabeled PDF form fields.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: Patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — generic authorization form requires selecting 'Personal Use' from nine options and filling in confusing self-referencing fields; buried page 2 note that the form 'is not required' for patient self-access underscores the mismatch.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but no material impediments — no notarization, no in-person requirement, right to revoke clearly stated, treatment-not-conditioned prominent, current reproductive health protections; vague fee language and no response time commitment are minor gaps.

overall.summary: Texas Oncology provides a well-built, bilingual fillable PDF with strong compliance features, but funnels patients through a generic third-party authorization form rather than offering a dedicated patient access pathway.
